summary: introduction RNA sequencing (RNA-seq) is widely used to measure expression levels of multiple genes simultaneously. RNA-seq is also used for genome annotation, enabling the study of gene transcription, RNA processing and various other biological functions. RNA-seq or small RNA sequencing (sRNA-seq) is indispensable for the annotation of non-coding genes. parallel analysis of RNA Ends and sequencing (PARE-seq), Cap Analysis of Gene Expression and sequencing (CAGE-seq) and Precision nuclear run-On and sequencing (PRO-seq) have been developed to identify the 5′ ends of mature RNAs (Bouvy-Liivrand et al., 2017). 5′ and 3′ end small RNAs (5′ and 3′ sRNAs) were found in human mitochondrial DNA. in this study, we demonstrated that 5′ and 3′ sRNAs alone can be used to annotate nuclear non-coding and mitochondrial genes. this method provides a simple and cost-effective way to annotate nuclear non-coding and mitochondrial genes and identify new steady RNAs. 5′ and 3′ sRNAs are defined as sRNA reads with lengths of 1550 bp. the cleavage sites
